bill.constitutionalAuthorityStatementText: [Congressional Record Volume 161, Number 7 (Wednesday, January 14, 2015)]From the Congressional Record Online through the Government Publishing Office [www.gpo.gov]By Mr. SEAN PATRICK MALONEY of New York:H.R. 358.Congress has the power to enact this legislation pursuantto the following:Article I, Section 8. ``The Congress shall have the power .. . to coin Money, regulate the Value thereof, and of foreignCoin, and fix the Standard of Weights and Measures;''[Page H407]

item.text: Referred to the House Committee on Financial Services.

item.fullName: Rep. Radewagen, Aumua Amata Coleman [R-AS-At Large]

item.text:
National Purple Heart Hall of Honor Commemorative Coin Act

Directs the Secretary of the Treasury to mint and issue $5 gold coins, $1 silver coins, and half-dollar clad coins emblematic of the National Purple Heart Hall of Honor.

Limits the minting of such coins to the one-year period beginning on January 1, 2017.

Prescribes surcharges for coin sales, which shall be paid to the National Purple Heart Hall of Honor, Inc., to help finance the construction of a new building and renovation of existing National Purple Heart Hall of Honor facilities.
item.name: Introduced in House

bill.title: National Purple Heart Hall of Honor Commemorative Coin Act

item.title: To require the Secretary of the Treasury to mint coins in commemoration of the National Purple Heart Hall of Honor.
National Purple Heart Hall of Honor Commemorative Coin Act
National Purple Heart Hall of Honor Commemorative Coin Act

latestAction.text: Referred to the House Committee on Financial Services.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
